Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Design and Control of Wireless Networks on Network-Information-Theoretic Foundations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Network resource allocation deals with efficiently managing the
scarce resources available with the objective of providing us
with practical algorithms to achieve high performance in
wireless networks. On the other hand, network information
theory develops conceptual tools to build new mechanisms to
exploit the full capacity of wireless networks. Currently there
is a significant gap between the information theoretic
capacities of wireless networks and the performances achieved
by existing resource allocation schemes.

This project aims to bridge these two separate perspectives to close
this performance gap. To that end, it develops practical network
algorithms over an underlying infrastructure of multiuser channels
along with the appropriate information theoretic mechanisms. To achieve
this task, it proceeds along the following main research thrusts: (1)
network design, which involves the optimal construction and dynamic
update of multiuser channels; (2) network control, based on joint
optimization of physical and the network layers and the development of
the necessary stochastic optimization tools; (3) design of
low-complexity multiuser channel schedulers with a near-optimal
performance; (4) performance evaluation of the developed algorithms
through real link-level measurements.

The outcome of the research has the potential to give us performance
gains by more than an order of magnitude, which will enable the design
and implementation of faster, more reliable, and more robust wireless
networks operating under a variety of conditions. Dissemination of the
research will be achieved by submitting the results for publication in
refereed scholarly journals, presentation in conferences and symposia,
and lectures and workshops in academic and industrial settings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Network resource allocation is the field that develops mechanisms to achieve optimal performance across multiple layers in wired and wireless networks. In parallel, network information theory provides us with the conceptual understanding to build mechanisms to exploit the full capacity of networks. This research combined these two separate perspectives and developed new theories, techniques, practical algorithms, and built real implementations for wireless network control to realize the maximum performance gains achievable. The outcome of our effort provided performance improvements for wireless networks by an order of magnitude  compared to the traditional network resource allocation schemes. Two sample performance graphs are attached for large wireless networks. Both figures illustrate the potential gains associated with exploitation of network information theoretic techniques that enable us to decode multiple transmissions simultaneously over the same frequency band. We integrated this technique into network control via a careful design of associated algorithms for power control, rate control, and code design.

With the realization that cybersecurity is one of the major priorities in the next generation networks, one of the directions we focused in our research is cybersecurity. Our goal was to develop the analytical underpinnings of wireless security that are rooted in a rigorous information theoretic foundation, in order to construct provably secure, highly efficient, and practically implementable network control algorithms and protocols. The beauty of information-theoretic security is that it exploits the inherent diversity in wireless channel conditions to provide “perfect secrecy,” regardless of the computational capabilities of the attackers. However, it suffers from key technical challenges that have so far rendered it virtually impractical. Our effort within this project was the first of its kind to provide a concrete pathway to making the promise of information theoretic secrecy a practical reality. Unlike traditional research on information theoretic secrecy, which primarily focuses on the physical layer, we will developed methodologies that unifies information theoretic secrecy with the fundamental building blocks for wireless network control (e.g., power control, congestion control, scheduling, and routing). We demonstrated substantial efficiencies and proposed network control mechanisms that protect the network and provide strong (information theoretic) security guarantees to have an impact in next generation wireless networks. Our evolutionary pathway also helps bolster current (computational) security primitives by unifying them with information theoretic paradigm. 

Our research also made a significant impact on implementation and real-world experimentation. We have built a number of different platforms and applications to demonstrate the efficacy of our scheme. Apart from the academic papers in top journals and conferences, this research lead to 1 patent, 2 provisional patents, and 1 mobile app that won the third prize in an app contest. The major applications that we have focused on include V2X and intra-vehicular communication, MIMO systems, and LTE networks. Our setup for V2X physical-layer security is given in an attached figure as well.

This project made a major educational impact. Students on this project learned a wide range of methodologies spanning stochastic optimization, distributed algorithms, wireless communication, as well as hands-on experimentation and data analysis. Apart from developing new undergraduate and graduate-level classes, the PI introduced project work in the existing classes that addressed various aspects of physical layer design, channel estimation and network optimization. The PI will recruited and trained multiple students from underrepresented groups.
